Let's call the length opposite to angle T as 'a', adjacent to it as 'b', and hypotenuse as 'c'. Given $\sin{R}=\frac{2}{5}$, we know that $a=2$ and $c=5$. Using the Pythagorean Theorem, we get $b= \sqrt{c^2 - a^2} = \sqrt{5^2 - 2^2} = \sqrt{21}$. Now, because triangles share corresponding parts when one is flipped over another line segment parallel to them, so do the ratios representing sides concerning each respective angle. That suggests our new ratio relating sin T becomes $(\text{opposite}/\text{hypotenuse})_{T}=(\text{adjacent}/\text{hypotenuse})_{R}$. Substituting what we already found out into equation above provides us, $$\sin{T}=\frac{b}{c}=\frac{\sqrt{21}}{5}$$

direct_answer.text: Without additional information regarding the relationship between angles \(R\), \(S\), and \(T\) in triangle \(RTS\), it isn't feasible to accurately calculate \(\sin T\) just from \(\sin R = \frac{2}{5}\). Typically, one needs to know at least one other angle besides right ones (\(\pi/2\) radians or equivalent degrees) when applying the law of sines—otherwise known as Sorensen’s theorem. Alternatively, having direct measurements of sides adjacent to each mentioned angle may prove useful too because the sine function also depends on them according to \[\text{{Law of Cosines}},\] typically used along with \[~\text{{law of cosine}}\right].
